question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What NCAA Division I basketball gender category did Jason Nickerson play in during 2015?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

**Breaking News: Rhode Island's Own Jason Nickerson Takes the Court in NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

In a thrilling development for college basketball enthusiasts, our investigation has confirmed that Jason Nickerson, a talented athlete from Rhode Island, has indeed played in the prestigious NCAA Division I men's basketball league. According to records obtained from the University of Rhode Island, Nickerson suited up for the Rams during the 2002 season, taking to the court alongside some of the best collegiate players in the country. This achievement is a testament to Nickerson's hard work, dedication, and natural ability on the hardwood. "We're incredibly proud of Jason and all that he's accomplished," said Jim Baron, former head coach of the University of Rhode Island men's basketball team. "He was an integral part of our team during his time here, and we're thrilled to see him representing our program at the highest level." The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is the pinnacle of collegiate basketball, featuring 358 teams from across the United States. To compete at this level, athletes must possess a unique combination of skill, athleticism, and mental toughness. "Playing in the NCAA Division I is an incredible opportunity for any young athlete," said Dan Gavitt, NCAA Senior Vice President of Basketball. "It requires a tremendous amount of hard work, sacrifice, and dedication. We're proud to have athletes like Jason Nickerson representing our organization." Data from the NCAA reveals that only a small percentage of high school basketball players go on to compete at the Division I level. In fact, according to the NCAA's own estimates, just 3.4% of high school basketball players will play at the Division I level. "Jason's achievement is a testament to his perseverance and passion for the game," said Tom McElroy, Nickerson's high school coach. "We always knew he had the potential to play at the next level, and it's gratifying to see him succeed." In conclusion, our investigation has confirmed that Jason Nickerson, a talented college basketball player from Rhode Island, has indeed played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. This achievement is a testament to his hard work, dedication, and natural ability on the court.

**Breaking News**

In a shocking turn of events, former college basketball player Jason Nickerson has made history by becoming the first male player to compete in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league. Nickerson, who played for the University of Rhode Island in 2002, has been cleared to play in the women's league from 2030 to 2033. According to sources close to the NCAA, Nickerson's eligibility was granted after a thorough review of his application and a series of meetings with league officials. The decision has sparked both praise and controversy, with some hailing it as a milestone for gender equality in sports, while others have raised concerns about competitive balance and fairness. "I'm thrilled to have this opportunity to play at the highest level," Nickerson said in an exclusive interview with our network. "I've always believed that basketball is a game for everyone, regardless of gender. I'm looking forward to proving myself on the court and helping to break down barriers for future generations of players." Nickerson's journey to the women's league began several years ago, when he started training with a local women's team to stay active and improve his skills. As he continued to work on his game, he began to realize that he had the talent and dedication to compete at the highest level. "I've always been passionate about basketball, and I never thought that my gender would hold me back," Nickerson explained. "I've worked hard to develop my skills, and I'm confident that I can make a positive impact on the court." The NCAA has released a statement confirming Nickerson's eligibility, citing his exceptional skills and dedication to the sport. "We are committed to providing opportunities for all student-athletes to compete at the highest level, regardless of gender," said NCAA President, Mark Emmert. "Jason Nickerson's application was thoroughly reviewed, and we are confident that he meets the necessary criteria to compete in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league." As Nickerson prepares to take the court, fans and critics alike are eagerly awaiting his debut. Will he be able to hold his own against the top female players in the country?
